metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: You can add two tensors using tensorA.add(tensorB) :

content.code_html:
const tensorA = tf.tensor([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]]);
const tensorB = tf.tensor([[1,-1], [2,-2], [3,-3]]);

// Tensor Addition
 const tensorNew = tensorA.add(tensorB);

// Result: [ [2, 1], [5, 2], [8, 3] ]

content.text: You can subtract two tensors using tensorA.sub(tensorB) :

content.code_html:
const tensorA = tf.tensor([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]]);
const tensorB = tf.tensor([[1,-1], [2,-2], [3,-3]]);

// Tensor Subtraction
 const tensorNew = tensorA.sub(tensorB);

// Result: [ [0, 3], [1, 6], [2, 9] ]

content.text: You can multiply two tensors using tensorA.mul(tensorB) :

content.code_html:
const tensorA = tf.tensor([1, 2, 3, 4]);
const tensorB = tf.tensor([4, 4, 2, 2]);

// Tensor Multiplication
 const tensorNew = tensorA.mul(tensorB);

// Result: [ 4, 8, 6, 8 ]

content.text: You can divide two tensors using tensorA.div(tensorB) :

content.code_html:
const tensorA = tf.tensor([2, 4, 6, 8]);
const tensorB = tf.tensor([1, 2, 2, 2]);

// Tensor Division
 const tensorNew = tensorA.div(tensorB);

// Result: [ 2, 2, 3, 4 ]

content.text: You can square a tensor using tensor.square() :

content.code_html:
const tensorA = tf.tensor([1, 2, 3, 4]);

// Tensor Square
 const tensorNew = tensorA.square();

// Result [ 1, 4, 9, 16 ]

content.text: The number of elements in a tensor is the product of the sizes in the shape.
content.html: The number of elements in a tensor is the product of the sizes in the shape.

content.text: Since there can be different shapes with the same size, it is often useful to reshape a tensor to other shapes with the same size.
content.html: Since there can be different shapes with the same size, it is often useful to reshape a tensor to other shapes with the same size.

content.text: You can reshape a tensor using tensor.reshape() :

content.code_html:
const tensorA = tf.tensor([[1, 2], [3, 4]]);
const tensorB = tensorA.reshape([4, 1]);

// Result: [ [1], [2], [3], [4] ]
